title: Synthetic Recap
body:
VANCOUVER — On a night where offense was at a premium, Clyde Drexler authored a performance for the ages, but it was a final, frantic moment that sealed a heartbreaking 93-92 victory for the Vancouver Grizzlies over his Houston Rockets.

In a game defined by defensive grit, Drexler was a sublime anomaly. The veteran guard put on a masterclass, pouring in a herculean 41 points while snatching 10 rebounds. He was the singular offensive engine for the Rockets, slicing through the Vancouver defense and carrying the scoring load almost entirely on his own. While his teammates struggled to find a rhythm, “Clyde the Glide” was soaring, keeping Houston within striking distance through sheer force of will.

The Grizzlies, however, countered with a balanced attack. Shareef Abdur-Rahim provided a steady 20 points and 9 rebounds, while Greg Anthony chipped in 15 points. The game teetered on a knife’s edge throughout the final quarter, a tense back-and-forth befitting a one-point final margin.

With the clock draining and the Rockets clinging to a slim lead, it all came down to one final possession. Drexler, who had willed his team to the brink of victory, could only watch as the Grizzlies’ Bryant Reeves rose to the occasion. “Big Country” hit the game-winning shot as time expired, sending the Vancouver crowd into a frenzy and stunning the Rockets.

The final horn sounded on a historic individual effort tragically undone by a single play. Drexler’s 41-point, 10-rebound tour de force will be remembered as one of the great individual performances of the era, but in the cruel ledger of the NBA, it goes down merely as a footnote in a devastating loss.
